entry.title: Biodegradable material mycelium in fashion industry
entry.content:
The application of biodegradable material mycelium in the fashion industry - A case study of Bolt Threads Company(proposal)

Keywords:

Biodegradable material, Sustainable environment, the Fashion industry, Bolt Threads company

Abstract:

This study report wants to find out what is the current usage situation of mycelium in the fashion industry and what will its future look like. Will it have a broader applicable market in the relatively developed regions by using biodegradable material to promote sustainable consciousness for people. Since fashion makes a sizeable contribution to climate change the whole industry is facing the transition risk. Therefore, using sustainable materials like mycelium can be an environmentally friendly alternative to materials like animal-based leather. Mycelium-based materials can be produced either as pure materials from liquid cultures of mycelium or as composites based on organic substrates. The process is simple to conduct by using little energy and water and it is fast growing and in massive production. This paper will examine the application of mycelium in the market and takes Bolt Threads company as an example in the fashion industry. Besides, the future development of mycelium including its opportunities and challenges will also be illustrated.

Introduction:

The growing population and rapid development of technology have led to an immense increase in greenhouse gas emissions and have caused serious climate change issues on our planet. The global fashion industry also called the textile industry is closely related to our daily life, over the past two decades, there has been an increasing consumer demand in the fashion industry (Gardetti & Muthu, 2020). Consumption is on the opposite side of sustainability. The fashion industry is concerned by the negative environmental and social impact it brings as it produces nearly 10% of CO2 annually (Niinimäki et al., 2020). The fashion industry is the second most polluting industry which has caused 20% of all global wastewater, with an anticipated 50% increase in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 (Bailey et al., 2022).

Literature review:

Outline:

  1. The changing environment ( Sustainability; Climate change issue )

  2. The development of the sustainable fashion industry (compare with the fast industry)

  3. The consumption behavior and environmental consciousness of consumers

  4. The use of biodegradable material (comparison with other materials)

Climate change is a global issue and we need to take a polycentric system to take action in reducing the greenhouse gases (GHGs) being emitted to society (Ostrom, 2010).

Sustainable fashion which is part of slow fashion often seen on the opposite side of fast fashion. Slow fashion is a concept that advocates for environmental and social justice, it centers on sustainability values such as good working conditions for workers and reducing environmental damages to the society (Henninger et al., 2016).

Fast fashion consumers look for constant change and new products at a relatively lower price frequently. Thus, timing is a priority for the fast fashion brands like Zara, H&M, etc. They need to get the costumes quickly and push for the latest trend (Bruce & Daly, 2006).

On the other hand, consumer ethics in relation to fashion consumption is considered a slow culture (McNeill & Moore, 2015). It takes time and education to minimize the attitude-behavior gap to be knowledgeable enough about innovative products for sustainable consumption (Shen et al., 2013).

The first thing to consider for sustainable fashion is the material. The choice of materials has a large impact on the overall footprint of clothing from cultivation land, fertilizer, and water use to processing energy, chemical, and water use to use microplastic pollution (Lacy et al., 2020).

For cotton biodegrades it requires nearly twice as much land as hemp per finished textiles. Cotton’s entire production process uses more than four times as much water as hemp. Most of the cotton is also not grown organically and relies on pesticides that will lead to negative effects on the environment and also human health (Parvin et al., 2020). Another issue with cotton is that while it will biodegrade, it’s treated with pesticides and dyes that can permeate soil once the fabric breaks down which damages the environment.

Animal agriculture is a leading contributor to climate change, and beef and leather-producing cattle are especially linked to global warming, deforestation, and water pollution. The Food and Agriculture Organization estimates that animal agriculture is responsible for between 14.5 percent and 18 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions, but 65 percent of that comes from cattle (Farra, 2021). While traditional leather and its alternatives are mainly produced from animals or synthetic materials, mycelium-based leather alternatives are fabricated through upcycling agriculture and forestry resembling leather in both the aesthetic texture and its properties.

Methodology:

This study report mainly focuses on using qualitative methods emphasizing exploratory research by using a case study approach to explore the future application of biodegradable material mycelium in the fashion industry, with a specific focus on Bolt Threads Company. Literature research will be conducted to collect information from commercial and academic articles. Besides, using descriptive research including secondary data from the company website and other industry reports to know more about the consumers’ preferences and behavior toward biodegradable materials in the fashion industry.

Case Study:

Bolt Threads is a California-based company that creates sustainable materials by engineering proteins inspired by nature. They invent cutting-edge materials for the fashion and beauty industries to put us on a path toward a more sustainable future. One of their products is called Mylo™ which is a leather alternative made from mycelium, the complex thread structure that allows fungi to grow (Chung, 2021). It is a high-quality alternative for animal and synthetic-based leather that has the potential to become commercially viable. Mylo is soft, supple, and free of harmful chemicals usually used in leather production. It emits fewer greenhouse gases and uses less water and resources than animal leather.

Mycelium is a type of fungus that grows underground and forms a network of thread-like structures. It has been found to have several properties that make it suitable for use in the fashion industry (Antinori et al., 2020). Mycelium is biodegradable, which means that it can decompose naturally in the environment, and it is lightweight and flexible thus it is suitable to be used in clothing and accessories. Also it can be grown in a controlled environment, which makes it a sustainable alternative to traditional materials (Vandelook et al., 2021) and it usually takes a shorter time within two weeks to cultivate a massive amount.

Mylo has made a consortium with its partners such as Adidas, Kering, lululemon, and Stella McCartney. They are combined based on mission alignment, and high standards of quality. They are banded together to invest in meaningful material innovation with Mylo. Debuted by consortium partner Adidas in April 2021, the Stan Smith Mylo™ is the first-ever shoe made with Mylo. Adidas pays homage to a classic with a new pledge of responsibility to find material solutions inspired by nature (Thread, 2022).

Conclusion:

Opportunities: Mycelium has a unique texture that can be manipulated to create different finishes, making it an interesting material for fashion designers to work with. The texture of mycelium can be manipulated to mimic the look and feel of other materials, such as leather or suede, which can be appealing to consumers. Incorporating mycelium into fashion designs can also help fashion brands improve their sustainability and eco-friendly credentials, which is becoming increasingly important to consumers. Brands that use sustainable and eco-friendly materials are likely to be viewed more positively by consumers and are more likely to attract environmentally conscious consumers. The use of mycelium in the fashion industry is still a relatively new concept, which presents opportunities for designers to create new and innovative products that stand out in a crowded market. Designers can experiment with different shapes, sizes, and textures, which can help create new and exciting fashion products.

Challenges: Mycelium is currently produced in small batches, making it difficult to scale up production to meet the demands of the fashion industry. New production methods need to be developed to address this issue. Also, the production can be expensive, which can make it challenging for designers to incorporate mycelium into their designs and for consumers to afford mycelium-based products. Cost-effective production methods need to be developed to address this issue as well.

Solutions: While mycelium is a durable material, it may not be as durable as some traditional materials. This means that products made from mycelium may have a shorter lifespan. Designers need to ensure that mycelium-based products are durable and can withstand normal wear and tear. Also, consumers may be hesitant to purchase products made from a relatively unknown material. Designers and manufacturers need to educate consumers about the benefits of mycelium-based materials and address any concerns they may have about the safety and quality of these products. The problems need to be addressed for the mycelium to become a more widely adopted material in the fashion industry. Despite these challenges, the potential benefits of mycelium-based materials make them an exciting and promising area of innovation for the fashion industry.

Finding agent middlemen, wholesalers and retailers can also have a huge impact on increasing the sales of Yadea’s Y1S. Describe the market in which the product is to be sold

The United Kingdom which comprises England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland locates in the Western part of the European countries which is surrounded by four seas. To the South is the English Channel, which separates it from continental Europe. to the East by the North Sea, and to the West by the Irish Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. There are also 24 international airports in the UK which provide a variety of cheap flights. In addition, Eurostar’s high-speed train services running frequently can travel from London to the continent in just over two hours, every day of the week.

Under the country code +44, there were a total of 111.04 million connections in 2020. In addition to broadband Internet connections, around 95% of all residents have access to the Internet. Around 41% have a fast Internet connection.

  1. Consumer buying habits

b. Product feature preference: The customers would care about the price, quality, design, brand, and environmental benefits it can bring to society. 3. Balance of payment situation:

The balance of payments is the record of all international financial transactions made by a country’s residents, including the current account, the capital account, and the financial account. All trades conducted by private and public sectors are accounted for in the BOP to determine how much money is going in and out of a country. The data published by the International Monetary Fund has shown the BOP of the current account balance from the year 1970 to 2021(Bank, 2022). From 1997 till now, the UK has been in a current account deficit condition. The current account deficit is a measurement of a country’s trade where the value of the goods and services it imports exceeds the value of the products it exports.

4. Exchange rates

The UK is a floating exchange rate regime in which the price of a country’s currency is determined by the foreign exchange markets. It is based on the supply and demand of one currency relative to another. The United Kingdom entered the floating exchange rate regime in 1972, along with most other countries in the world, leaving the Bretton Woods system behind. The current rate of exchange on October 18th of the British Pound to the Chinese Yuan is 8.165. And the overall exchange rate for the past year has declined from around 8.8 in October 2021 to 8.1 in October 2022(Barchart, 2022).

L: Trade Restriction

1. Embargoes:

There are 38 trade barriers from the UK to China for example sectors like food and drink, healthcare services, pharmaceuticals and biotechnology etc. In the food and drink sector, the UK has not permitted cherries, lamb meat, and hops to export to China(Government.UK, 2020). There is also a partial arms embargo on China, and the military items covered by the embargo are lethal weapons Field(Government.UK, December, 2020) such as machine guns, large-caliber weapons, bombs, torpedoes, rockets and missiles.

2. Quotas:

We can look at the UK tariff rate quotas for 2022. In the commodity part, there is poultry, pigment, cereals, olive oil, rice, beef, garlic, sugar, milk products, and eggs(Government.UK, 2022b). There is an order number and annual quantity available for each order, and it can be divided into 4 sub-periods of the available quantity. For more information visit the website of the UK trade quotas(Government.UK, 2022c).

3. Import taxes:

UK import tax will vary depending on several factors, including the type of item sent, the value, the country of origin, and the intended use including personal or commercial. You pay VAT when you buy the goods or to the delivery company before you receive them. VAT is not charged on goods that are gifts worth £39 or less. If you have to pay VAT to the delivery company, it’s charged on the total package value, including the value of the goods postage, packaging and insurance, and any duty you owe. You will need to pay VAT to the delivery company if the goods are gifts sent to you by someone else and worth more than £39 and the excise goods(Government.UK, 2022a).

4. Tariffs:

The UK Global Tariff (UKGT) is the UK’s first independent tariff policy which replaced the EU Common External Tariff (CET) which applied until 31 December 2020. This tariff entered into force on 1 January 2021. The Government has published the UK Global Tariff (UKGT) which applies to all goods imported unless:

  • the country imports come from has a preferential trade agreement
  • an exception applies, such as a relief or tariff suspension
  • the goods come from developing countries covered by the Generalised Scheme of Preferences

5. Licensing:

The UK Government Licensing Framework (UKGLF) provides a policy and legal overview of the arrangements for licensing the use and re-use of public sector information both in the central government and the wider public sector. It sets out best practices and standardizes licensing principles. In the context of the UKGLF, the licenses ensure that users are aware of the need to use the information responsibly and not in ways that mislead others. The UKGLF provides a coherent standard approach to licensing through a portfolio of licensing solutions developed to cover the following situations field (Archives, 2016).

  • Free use and re-use for all purposes both commercial and non-commercial-the Open Government Licence

  • Free use and re-use for non-commercial purposes only-the Non-Commercial Government Licence

  • Where charges are made for the re-use of information, including in the context of s102 of the Protection of Freedoms Act 20121 and under the Re-use of Public Sector Information Regulations 2015-the Charged Licence

6. Customs duties:

You’ll be charged Customs Duty on all goods sent from outside the UK (or the UK and the EU if you’re in Northern Ireland) if they’re either excise goods or worth more than £135. If you’re charged Customs Duty, you’ll need to pay it on both the price paid for the goods; postage, packaging, and insurance. In the UK you pay Customs Duty on excise goods of any value

M: Extent of economic activity not included in cash income activities

1. Countertrades:

Many governments reduce imbalances in trade between countries using a countertrade system of international trading. Companies that consider countertrade typically want to expand into a foreign market, increase sales, build customer and supplier relationships, and overcome liquidity challenges. This type of international trade is more common in developing countries with limited foreign exchange or credit facilities.

Countertrade can be classified into three broad categories: barter, counterpurchase, and offset. Bartering is the oldest countertrade arrangement. It is the direct exchange of goods and services with an equivalent value but with no cash settlement. For example, a bag of nuts might be exchanged for coffee beans or meat. Under a counterpurchase arrangement, the exporter sells goods or services to an importer and agrees to also purchase other goods from the importer within a specified period. The exporters entering into a counterpurchase arrangement must use a trading firm to sell the goods they purchase and will not use the goods themselves. In an offset arrangement, the seller assists in marketing products manufactured by the buying country or allows part of the exported product’s assembly to be carried out by manufacturers in the buying country. This practice is common in aerospace, defense and certain infrastructure industries.

2. Foreign aid received:

The UK’s trading relationships with developing countries positively impact UK consumers by providing a wider choice of everyday goods at lower costs, making household incomes go further. For UK businesses, imports from developing countries support UK exports. For example, according to UN Comtrade data, in 2016, 48% of UK imports of un-processed tea came from Kenya, 10% of imports of prepared fish came from Ghana, and 21% of T-shirts came from Bangladesh. By helping developing countries trade more with the UK and the rest of the world, the UK can support their economic development which helps drive growth and jobs in a way that aid-spending alone cannot (Lee, 2018).

N: Labor force

1. Size:

The employment rate has decreased since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, and it increased at the end of 2020. However, the employment rate decreased from June to August 2022, and self-employed workers increased. Compared with the previous three-month period from March to May 2022 which had a higher employment rate than other recent periods(Statistics, 2022).

2. Unemployment rates:

The unemployment rate had generally been falling since late 2013 until the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. It increased until the end of 2020 but has now returned to pre-coronavirus pandemic levels. Over the latest three-month period, the unemployment rate decreased to the lowest rate of around 3.5%.

O: Inflation rates:

The inflation rate in the United Kingdom was 10.1 percent in September 2022, compared with 9.9 percent in August 2022. This is the joint-highest inflation rate recorded for the Consumer Price Index (CPI) in the UK, with prices also rising by 10.1 percent a few weeks earlier in July 2022 (Statistica, 2022). During the most recent month, housing costs, such as energy and water, had the most significant price increases.

entry.title: The Uk's Political system
entry.content:
Summary:

The British political system is a two-party system and in order to measure a country’s political stability, we can look at the indicator of the political stability index. The latest data from 2020 shows that the UK scores 0.47 which proves that the UK has a relatively stable government compared with the average level in the world. The 2022 International IP shows the UK has ranked No.2 out of the 55 economies which indicates that the UK has a mature law and supervision system to continue to promote and develop the intellectual property market. The fundamental principles of business culture in the United Kingdom are courtesy, politeness, discipline, and punctuality and most British businesspeople are following a rational and pragmatic approach.

C: Political system

Political structure: Britain is a constitutional monarchy governed by a king or a queen and it is also a parliamentary democracy whose government is controlled by a parliament that has been elected by the people. The highest positions in the government are filled by the members of the directly elected parliament.

Political parties: The British political system is a two-party system. Since the 1920s, the two dominant parties have been the Conservative Party and the Labour Party. In September of 2022, Liz Truss became the new prime minister of the UK after meeting the queen at Balmoral. Her first significant act as prime minister is to deal with the high price of energy and made it affordable to the people of the UK.

Stability of the government: To measure a country’s political stability, we can look at the indicator of the political stability index. It ranges in degree from -2.5 meaning unstable to +2.5 which means stable. The given data shows from the year 1996 to 2020, the average value for the United Kingdom was 0.48. With a minimum of 0.08 points in 2018 and a maximum of 1.04 points in 2000. In the latest data from 2020, the world average value based on 194 countries is -0.07, and the UK scores 0.47 (Bank, 2020). The compared result proves that the UK has a relatively stable government with better performance than the average level in the world. A general conclusion can be obtained through this observation from the British government. The stable political environment is of great opportunity to expand our market in this country.

Special taxes in the UK:

In 2021/22, the UK government raised over £915 billion a year in receipts – income from taxes and other sources. This is equivalent to around 39% of the size of the UK economy, as measured by GDP. In cash terms, the hardest hit tax in 2020/21 was VAT, where receipts were over £17 billion lower, compared with 2019/20. Consumers were less able to go out and spend during the pandemic, and Government policies, such as cutting VAT from 20% to 5% for the ‘hospitality, accommodation, and attractions sector, have also affected VAT receipt (Matthew, 2022).

For example, the carbon tax. A Carbon tax aims to make individuals and firms pay the full social cost of carbon pollution. This special tax will encourage individuals to reduce pollution and encourage them to use more environmentally products such as solar power. It also makes polluters pay the external cost of carbon emissions. In contrast, there exist some problems, for example, enterprises may avoid paying carbon tax by secretly polluting the greenhouse gases in the environment (Pettinger, 2020 ). Under this scenario, the government should strengthen education on ethical behavior and set guidelines and regulations for the people to follow.

Local government: Normally, Government is responsible for deciding how the country is run, they set taxes, and deciding how to best deliver public services such as the National Health Service, and welfare benefits such as the state pension. In the United Kingdom, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland have their devolved governments and each with varying powers. The parliament’s job is to look closely at the Government’s plans and to monitor the way they are running things, they work on behalf of the government’s decision by examining new proposals closely and suggesting improvements, checking how public money is being spent, and tracking how new laws are working out in practice (Parliament, 2022).

D: Legal system

Judiciary system: The UK does not have a constitution that is contained in a written constitutional instrument. It is to be found in the statutes passed by Parliament and in the common law, which developed over historical reasons. As a state made up of several separate jurisdictions, the United Kingdom does not have a single unified legal system. The UK lacks a written constitution on the current political and legal institutions, also their institutions did not separate the functions and powers of the three different branches of the state which are the executive, the legislature, and the judiciary (Judiciary, 2022).

For example, the government is made up of MPs and peers who are also members of the legislature including the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The UK public elects 650 Members of Parliament to represent their interests and concerns in the House of Commons. The House of Lords is the second chamber of the UK Parliament. It plays a crucial role in examining bills, questioning government action, and investigating public policy. In this case, it is usually quite intricate and requires some time to make a unified decision or pass through the law such as the Brexit issue. If a company wants to do business in the UK it would be better to choose a time after the factionalism.

Intellectual property: IP usually gives the creator an exclusive right over the use of his creation for a certain period. Copyright, patents, designs, and trademarks are common rights for intellectual property protection. 179 countries have signed up to the Berne Convention which lays down a common framework and agreement between nations concerning intellectual property rights. The 2022 International IP Index published by the US Chamber of Commerce has given out the rankings and the indicators of the overall score of IP. The UK has ranked No.2 out of the 55 economies. It has a high ranking in the sector of copyright and trademark and a relatively lower ranking in the patents and design rights (commerce, 2022). Copyright law originated in the United Kingdom from a concept of common law which is the Statute of Anne 1709. It became statutory with the passing of the Copyright Act of 1911. The current act is the Copyright, Designs, and Patents Act 1988(service, 2022). The UK has a mature law and supervision system to continue to promote and develop the intellectual property market.

E: Social Organization

Group behavior: Social organization refers to the network of relationships in a group and how they interconnect with each other. For example, Social Value UK is a Joint Member Network of Social Value International, the global standard-setting organization for social value and impact management. Social Value International has also partnered with the UNDP and SDG Impact to support the adoption of the SDG Impact Standards globally. Social Value UK’s mission is to change the way society accounts for value through principles, practice, people, and power and develop guidance, tools, and support to help achieve the principles. Businesses can make a cooperation with these organizations and achieve common goals to enhance customers’ favorability and their reputation.

The UK social classes:

Approximated Social Grade with its six categories A, B, C1, C2, D, and E is a socio-economic classification produced by the ONS (UK Office for National Statistics) by applying an algorithm developed by members of the MRS Census & Geodemographics Group. It applies to every Household Reference Person (HRP) aged 16 to 64 (Geographics, 2014).

Social GradeDescription% HRP population (UK)
ABHigher & intermediate managerial, administrative, professional occupations22.17
C1Supervisory, clerical & junior managerial, administrative, professional occupations30.84
C2Skilled manual occupations20.94
DESemi-skilled & unskilled manual occupations, Unemployed and lowest grade occupations26.05

From the data in the table, we can tell more than half of the proportion of people in the UK are in the middle class and above. It is clear for the company to target its customer to a specific group of social classes.

Clubs: The Equality Act 2010 brings together harmonizes, in some respects extends previous equality laws. It aims to make it more consistent, clearer, and easier to follow, to make society fairer. The Act protects people from discrimination based on protected characteristics. Examples of associations include private clubs such as golf and other sports clubs, ex-forces clubs, alumni clubs, social clubs, working men’s clubs, gaming clubs, and drinking clubs. Some charities also meet the definition of an association, for example, the Scout Association and Girlguiding UK. Such charities are also subject to additional provisions relating to the provision of charitable benefits.

Subcultures: Since 2001, the foreign-born share of the population has doubled to about nine million. Meanwhile, the number of those from an ethnic minority background, including ‘White Other’, has more than doubled to over 13 million, their share of the population rising from 10% to 21%. Just over one-third of all births now involve at least one foreign-born parent and one in three pupils in English state-funded schools are from an ethnic minority background. The (UK, 2021) Gaming and non-mainstream religious groups are the two leading subcultures in the UK today, according to research that highlights the value to marketers of tapping into niche cultural groups. (WARC, 2020) Overall, 73% connect with subcultures virtually. And of those online-only connectors, two-thirds are younger (67% are under 44) and are more likely to connect to gaming, body modification, fandom, and influencer subcultures. YouTube is the main platform for contact (38%) and Facebook communities remain at the heart of subculture involvement. Understanding the subcultures can be useful for the business to understand and better adapt to the local market.

F: Business customs and practices

The fundamental principles of business culture in the United Kingdom are courtesy, politeness, discipline, and punctuality. Most British businesspeople are following a rational and pragmatic approach. Only on rare occasions, a commitment is announced right away, while agreements need to be formalized in writing. Due to the high frequency of meetings, people working in an office environment are often away from their desks. (Expatica, 2022) This accounts for the comparatively high number of memos sent and received in a UK company. So, we need to arrange appointments in advance. Dress codes in the UK are still comparatively strict. Colleagues appreciate a sense of fashion and quality. While men wear suits, ties, and striped or colored shirts and black shoes while women wear suits with trousers or skirts or normally in dresses, often with high heels. In most companies, colleagues enjoy an after-work drink together on a Friday night. Apart from this custom, the tendency is to keep work and private life strictly separated. Invitations to someone’s private home are gestures of affection and sympathy, which is uncommon between mere business partners. Colleagues exchange business cards before or at the beginning of a meeting. A card usually displays someone’s job title, first and surname. Academic titles are not necessarily on a business card unless they are relevant to your work. It is essentially important to understand its local customs when doing business with the British people.
